stem: A 45-year-old has spirometry: FEV1 62% predicted, FVC 88% predicted, FEV1/FVC 0.56. Which interpretation is most accurate?
rationale_correct: A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio indicates obstruction; FVC is preserved, supporting a primary obstructive pattern.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because low ratio defines obstruction. | B: Restriction requires reduced FVC/TLC with normal or high ratio. | C: Ratio is abnormal. | D: Mixed requires low ratio and low FVC/TLC.
common_trap: Calling restriction just because FEV1 is low.
exam_logic: Use FEV1/FVC to classify obstruction first.

stem: Spirometry shows FEV1 78% predicted, FVC 70% predicted, FEV1/FVC 0.86. What is the best next step to confirm the suspected defect?
option_b: Give bronchodilator and repeat spirometry only
rationale_correct: A normal/high ratio with low FVC suggests restriction, but confirmation requires TLC measurement.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct confirmatory test. | B: Bronchodilator helps assess reversibility, not confirm restriction. | C: PEF is effort-dependent and not confirmatory. | D: Imaging may help etiology but does not confirm physiologic restriction.

stem: Which change after bronchodilator meets common criteria for significant reversibility?
option_b: FEV1 increases by 12% and at least 200 mL
rationale_correct: Significant bronchodilator response is commonly defined as an increase in FEV1 (or FVC) of at least 12% and 200 mL.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Too small. | B: Correct threshold. | C: Not reversibility. | D: Ratio change alone is not the criterion.
common_trap: Using percent change only without volume threshold.

stem: A flow-volume loop shows flattening of the inspiratory limb with relatively preserved expiratory limb. Which condition best matches this pattern?
rationale_correct: Variable extrathoracic upper-airway obstruction characteristically flattens the inspiratory limb (e.g., vocal cord dysfunction).
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Intrathoracic variable obstruction flattens expiratory limb more. | B: Correct for inspiratory flattening. | C-D: Produce scooped expiratory limb rather than isolated inspiratory flattening.
common_trap: Confusing asthma with upper-airway obstruction patterns.
exam_logic: Match loop limb flattening to obstruction location.

stem: A flow-volume loop shows flattening of the expiratory limb with relatively preserved inspiratory limb. Which is most consistent with this finding?
rationale_correct: Variable intrathoracic obstruction tends to limit expiratory flow more, flattening the expiratory limb.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct. | B: Fixed obstruction flattens both inspiratory and expiratory limbs. | C: Extrathoracic variable obstruction flattens inspiratory limb. | D: Not normal if expiratory limb is flattened.
common_trap: Calling fixed obstruction when only one limb is affected.
exam_logic: Use limb affected to localize obstruction.

stem: A flow-volume loop shows plateau (flattening) of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs. What does this most strongly suggest?
rationale_correct: Fixed upper-airway obstruction (e.g., tracheal stenosis) produces flow limitation in both inspiration and expiration, flattening both limbs.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct classic pattern. | B: Asthma mainly scoops expiratory limb without inspiratory plateau. | C: Restriction reduces volumes but loop shape differs. | D: Effort can affect curves but classic bilateral plateau is high-yield for fixed obstruction.
common_trap: Blaming effort when loop has classic fixed pattern.
exam_logic: Bilateral plateau = fixed obstruction until proven otherwise.

stem: A patient has obstructive spirometry and a reduced DLCO. Which diagnosis is most consistent with this combination?
rationale_correct: Emphysema destroys alveolar-capillary surface area, lowering DLCO; chronic bronchitis often has a more preserved DLCO.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: DLCO often normal/preserved in chronic bronchitis. | B: Correct. | C-D: Not classic for obstructive pattern with low DLCO.
common_trap: Assuming all COPD phenotypes have low DLCO.
exam_logic: Use DLCO to differentiate emphysema vs bronchitis.

sub_concept: DLCO normal vs low in asthma
stem: A patient has episodic wheeze with obstructive spirometry and a normal-to-high DLCO. What does this pattern most suggest?
rationale_correct: DLCO is typically normal or elevated in asthma; emphysema lowers DLCO.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Emphysema lowers DLCO. | B: Correct. | C: Fibrosis typically restrictive with low DLCO. | D: PH lowers DLCO without classic obstructive spirometry.
common_trap: Mislabeling asthma as emphysema because of obstruction.
exam_logic: DLCO helps separate asthma from emphysema.

sub_concept: Air trapping vs restriction using RV/TLC
stem: Lung volumes show TLC 98% predicted and RV 160% predicted with increased RV/TLC. What does this most strongly indicate?
rationale_correct: A high RV with normal TLC indicates air trapping; restriction would reduce TLC.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct air trapping. | B: Restriction requires low TLC. | C: RV/TLC is abnormal. | D: Diffusion defect is assessed by DLCO, not RV/TLC.
common_trap: Calling restriction because patient is dyspneic.
exam_logic: Use TLC to confirm restriction; RV/TLC highlights air trapping.

stem: Which finding most strongly indicates an unacceptable spirometry maneuver?
option_a: A rapid start with good effort and repeatable values
option_b: Cough during the first second of exhalation
option_c: At least 6 seconds of exhalation with a plateau
rationale_correct: Cough in the first second can falsely alter FEV1 and makes the maneuver unacceptable for interpretation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Acceptable features. | B: Correctâ€”invalidates FEV1. | C: Suggests acceptability. | D: Suggests repeatability.
exam_logic: Reject invalid maneuvers before interpreting results.
